He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (n == 0) return 0;\n    \n    //@ assert ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    if (k < 2) return 0;\n\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n\n    if (k >= 2) {\n        n2 = (k - 4) / 4 + 1;\n        n2 = n - n4;\n        n3 = 0;\n        n5 = 0;\n        \n        if (2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k && n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n) {\n            return n2;\n        }\n    }\n\n    if (k >= 5) {\n        n5 = (k - That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int exploreConfigurations(int remainingN, int remainingK, int currentN2, int *minN2) {\n        if (remainingN < 0 || remainingK < 0) {\n            return 0;\n        }\n        if (remainingN == 0 && remainingK == 0) {\n            if (currentN2 < *minN2) {\n                *minN2 = currentN2;\n            }\n            return 1;\n        }\n        int found = 0;\n        found |= exploreConfigurations(remainingN - 1, remainingK - 2, currentN2 + 1, minN2);\n        found |= exploreConfigurations(remainingN - 1, remainingK - 3, currentN2, minN2);\n        found |= exploreConfigurations(remainingN - 1, remainingK - 4, currentN2, minN2);\n        found |= exploreConfigurations(remainingN - 1, remainingK - 5, currentN2, minN2);\n        return found;\n    }\n    int minN2 = n + 1;\n    exploreConfigurations(n, k, 0, &minN2);\n    return minN2;\n}\n",

                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (n == 0 || k < 2) return 0;\n    int result = n + 1;\n\n    for (int n2 = 0; n2 <= n; ++n2) {\n        for (int n3 = 0; n3 <= n - n2; ++n3) {\n            for (int n4 = 0; n4 <= n - n2 - n3; ++n4) {\n                int n5 = n - n2 - n3 - n4;\n                if (2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k) {\n                    if (n2 < result) {\n                        result = n2;\n                    }\n                }\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n    return result;\n}\n",

He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (n == 0 || k < 2) return 0;\n    if (k % 5 == 0 && k / 5 <= n) return 0;\n\n    int result = n + 1;\n    if (2 <= k && n >= 1) {\n        int res = 1 + calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int min_n2 = n;\n    int found = 0;\n\n    int consider(int n2, int n3, int n4, int n5) {\n        if (2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k && n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n) {\n            if (!found || n2 < min_n2) {\n                min_n2 = n2;\n                found = 1;\n            }\n        }\n        return 0;\n    }\n    \n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    \n    int rec_n5(int n5) {\n        if (n5 > n) return 0;\n        n4 = 0;\n        int rec_n4(int n4) {\n            if (n4 > n - n5) return 0;\n            n3 = 0;\n            int rec_n3(int n3) {\n                if (n3 > n - n5 - n4) return 0;\n                n2 = n - n5 - n4 - n3;\n                if (n2 >= 0 && n2 <= n) {\n                    consider(n2, n3, n4, n5);\n                }\n                return rec_n3(n3 + 1);\n            }\n            rec_n3(0);\n            return rec_n4(n4 + 1);\n        }\n        rec_n4(0);\n        return rec_n5(n5 + 1);\n    }\n    \n    rec_n5(0);\n    \n    return min_n2;\n}\n",

The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams.                     "gpt_output": "```c\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (n == 0) return 0;\n\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    n2 = k / 2;\n\n    if (k >= n * 2) {\n        return n;\n    }\n\n    // Try all valid combinations to find the minimal n2\n    if (k % 2 == 0) {\n        n2 = k / 2;\n        if (n2 <= n) {\n            n3 = n - n2;\n            if (3 * n3 >= k - 2 * n2) {\n                return n2;\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n    if (k % 3 == 0) {\n        for (int temp3 = k / 3; temp3 >= 0; temp3--) {\n            n3 = temp3;\n            n2 = (k - 3 * n3) / 2;\n            if (2 * n2 + 3 * n3 == k && n2 + n3 <= n) {\n                return n2;\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n    if (k % 4 == 0) {\n        for (int temp4 = k / 4; temp4 >= 0; temp4--) {\n            n4 = temp4;\n            n2 = (k - 4 * n4) / 2;\n            if (2 * n2 + 4 * n4 == k && n2 + n4 <= n) {\n                return n2;\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n    if (k % 5 == 0) {\n        for (int temp5 = k / 5; temp5 >= 0; temp5--) {\n            n5 = temp5;\n            n2 = (k - 5 * n5) / 2;\n            if (2 * n2 + 5 * n5 == k && n2 + n5 <= n) {\n                return n2;\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n    // Recursive exploration for deeper combinations\n    if (k >= 5) {\n        int res2 = calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - 1, k - 2);\n        int res3 = calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - 1, k - 3);\n        int res4 = calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - 1, k - 4);\n        int res5 = calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - 1, k - 5);\n        return res2 < res3 ? (res2 < res4 ? (res2 < res5 ? res2 : res5) : (res4 < res5 ? res4 : res5))\n                            : (res3 < res4 ? (res3 < res5 ? res3 : res5) : (res4 < res5 ? res4 : res5));\n    }\n\n    return k / 2;\n}\n```",

                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (n == 0) return 0;\n\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    n2 = k / 2;\n\n    if (k >= n * 2) {\n        return n;\n    }\n\n    // Try all valid combinations to find the minimal n2\n    if (k % 2 == 0) {\n        n2 = k / 2;\n        if (n2 <= n) {\n            n3 = n - n2;\n            if (3 * n3 >= k - 2 * n2) {\n                return n2;\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n    if (k % 3 == 0) {\n        for (int temp3 = k / 3; temp3 >= 0; temp3--) {\n            n3 = temp3;\n            n2 = (k - 3 * n3) / 2;\n            if (2 * n2 + 3 * n3 == k && n2 + n3 <= n) {\n                return n2;\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n    if (k % 4 == 0) {\n        for (int temp4 = k / 4; temp4 >= 0; temp4--) {\n            n4 = temp4;\n            n2 = (k - 4 * n4) / 2;\n            if (2 * n2 + 4 * n4 == k && n2 + n4 <= n) {\n                return n2;\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n    if (k % 5 == 0) {\n        for (int temp5 = k / 5; temp5 >= 0; temp5--) {\n            n5 = temp5;\n            n2 = (k - 5 * n5) / 2;\n            if (2 * n2 + 5 * n5 == k && n2 + n5 <= n) {\n                return n2;\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n    // Recursive exploration for deeper combinations\n    if (k >= 5) {\n        int res2 = calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - 1, k - 2);\n        int res3 = calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - 1, k - 3);\n        int res4 = calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - 1, k - 4);\n        int res5 = calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - 1, k - 5);\n        return res2 < res3 ? (res2 < res4 ? (res2 < res5 ? res2 : res5) : (res4 < res5 ? res4 : res5))\n                            : (res3 < res4 ? (res3 < res5 ? res3 : res5) : (res4 < res5 ? res4 : res5));\n    }\n\n    return k / 2;\n}\n",

It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int min_n2 = n; That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int possible_configuration_helper(int n, int k, int n2, int n3, int n4, int n5) {\n        if (n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 > n || 2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 > k) return n;\n        if (n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n && 2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k) return n2;\n\n        if (n2 > 0) {\n            int res1 = possible_configuration_helper(n, k, n2 - 1, n4 + 1, n5);\n            int res3 = possible_configuration_helper(n, k, n2, n3 - 1, n4, n5 + 1);\n            return res2 < res3 ? res2 : res3;\n        }\n\n        if (n4 > 0) {\n            int res3 = possible_configuration_helper(n, k, n2, n3, n4 -                     "tokens_used": 1433,
                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5, max_n2;\n    n5 = n4 = n3 = n2 = 0;\n    n5 = (k - 2 * n) / 3;\n    if (n5 > n) n5 = n;\n    k -= 5 * n5;\n    n -= n5;\n    \n    n4 = (k - 2 * n) / 2;\n    if (n4 > n) n4 = n;\n    k -= 4 * n4;\n    n -= n4;\n    \n    n3 = (k - 2 * n);\n    if (n3 > n) n3 = n;\n    k -= 3 * n3;\n    n -= n3;\n    \n    n2 = k / 2;\n    if (n2 + n3 > n) n2 = n - n3;\n    \n    max_n2 = (k - 3 * n3 - 4 * n4 - 5 * n5) / 2;\n    n2 = max_n2 < n2 ? max_n2 : n2;\n    \n    return n2;\n}\n",

Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2 = 0, n3 = 0, n4 = 0, n5 = 0;\n    if (k >= 5 && n > 0) {\n        n5 = k / 5 <= n ? The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int choose_min(int n_remaining, int k_remaining, int n2, int n3, int n4, int n5) {\n        if (k_remaining == 0) {\n            return n_remaining + n2;\n        } else if (k_remaining >= 5 && n_remaining > 0) {\n            return choose_min(n_remaining - 1, k_remaining - 5, n2, n3, n4, n5 + 1);\n        } else if (k_remaining >= 4 && n_remaining > 0) {\n            return choose_min(n_remaining - 1, k_remaining - 4, n2, n3, n4 + 1, n5);\n        } else if (k_remaining >= 3 && n_remaining > 0) {\n            return choose_min(n_remaining - 1, k_remaining - 3, n2, n3 + 1, n4, n5);\n        } else if (k_remaining >= 2 && n_remaining > 0) {\n            return choose_min(n_remaining - 1, k_remaining - 2, n2 + 1, n3, n4, n5);\n        } else {\n            return n_remaining + n2;\n        }\n    }\n    \n    return choose_min(n, k, 0, 0, 0, 0);\n}\n",

He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. 2);\n        \n        return solved;\n    }\n\n    tryCombinations(0, 0, 0, 0, 0);\n    \n    return minExams;\n}\n",

The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 0) {\n        return n; // Base case to handle recursion, no more sum needed, assign rest to n2.\n    }\n\n    int total_exams = k / 5 + (k % 5) / 4 + ((k % 5) % 4) / 3 + (((k % 5) % 4) % 3) / 2;\n    int remainder = (((k % 5) % 4) % 3) % 2;\n\n    if (total_exams > n) {\n        return n; // Revert and adjust n2 accordingly if total_exams exceeds n.\n    }\n\n    if (remainder == 0) {\n        return total_exams;\n    } else {\n        // Try next possible smaller configuration\n        if (k >= 5 && k % 5 != 0) {\n            return 1 + calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - 1, k - 5);\n        } else if (k >= 4 && k % 4 != 0) {\n            return 1 + calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - 1, k - 4);\n        } else if (k >= 3 && k % 3 != 0) {\n            return 1 + calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - 1, k - 3);\n        } else if (k >= 2 && k % 2 != 0) {\n            return 1 + calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n - 1, k - 2);\n        }\n    }\n\n    return n; // Fallback, although theoretically unreachable.\n}\n",

He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    //@ assert ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    \n    // Start with n5, then adjust downwards\n    n5 = k / 5;\n    k = k -                     "tokens_used": 1434,
                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    //@ assert ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    n5 = (5 <= k && k / 5 <= n) ?                     "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2 = 0, n3 = 0, n4 = 0, n5 = 0;\n\n    if (k >= 5) {\n        n5 = k / 5;\n        if (n5 > n) n5 = n; That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    // Check possible numbers of n5, n4, n3, and n2 for which constraints are satisfied\n    int n5_max = k / 5;\n    int n2_result = n; That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2 = 0, n3 = 0, n4 = 0, n5 = 0;\n    \n    while (n5 <= n && 5 * n5 <= k) {\n        int sum = 5 * n5;\n        int remaining = k -                     "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2 = n, n3, n4, n5;\n\n    n5 = k / 5;\n    if (n5 > n) n5 = n;\n  \n    k -= 5 * n5;\n    n -= n5;\n    \n    n4 = k / 4;\n    if (n4 > n) n4 = n;\n    \n    k -= 4 * n4;\n    n -= n4;\n    \n    n3 = k / 3;\n    if (n3 > n) n3 = n;\n    \n    k -= 3 * n3;\n    n -= n3;\n\n    n2 = k / 2;\n    if (n2 > n) n2 = n;\n\n    return n2;\n}\n",

That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k < 2 * n) {\n        return 0;\n    } else if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    } else if (n > 0 && k >= 5 && (k - The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    \n    n5 = (k / 5 < n) ? k / 5 : n;\n    k -= 5 * n5;\n    n -= n5;\n\n    n4 = (k / 4 < n) ? k / 4 : n;\n    k -= 4 * n4;\n    n -= n4;\n\n    n3 = (k / 3 < n) ? k / 3 : n;\n    k -= 3 * n3;\n    n -= n3;\n\n    n2 = (k / 2 < n) ? k / 2 : n;\n    k -= 2 * n2;\n    n -= n2;\n\n    if (k > 0) {\n        if (n5 > 0 && n + 1 <= 50) {\n            return calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n + 1, k + 5) - 1;\n        }\n        if (n4 > 0 && n + 1 <= 50) {\n            return calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n + 1, k + 4) - 1;\n        }\n        if (n3 > 0 && n + 1 <= 50) {\n            return calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n + 1, k + 3) - 1;\n        }\n        if (n2 > 0 && n + 1 <= 50) {\n            return calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n + 1, k + 2) - 1;\n        }\n    }\n\n    return n2;\n}\n",

That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k == 3 * n) {\n        return 0;\n    }\n\n    if (n == 1 && k <= 5) {\n        if (k == 2) return 1;\n        if (k == 3) return 0;\n        if (k == 4) return 0;\n        if (k == 5) return 0;\n    }\n\n    for (n2 = 0; He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n\n    if (k < 2 * n) {\n        n2 = (k + 1) / 2;\n        if (2 * n2 >= k && n2 <= n) {\n            return n2;\n        }\n    }\n\n    if (k >= 5 * n) {\n        n5 = n;\n        if (2 * (n -                     "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        if (k <= 3 * n) {\n            return k - 2 * n;\n        }\n        if (k <= 4 * n) {\n            int n3 = n - (k - 2 * n) / 2;\n            int additional = (k - (2 * (n - n3) + 3 * n3)) / 4;\n            return (n3 + 1 == n || 3 * n3 + 4 * additional == k) ? n3 : n3 + additional + 1;\n        }\n        int n4 = n;\n        int required = k - 3 * n4;\n        return required / 2 + (required % 2 != 0);\n    }\n    return 0;\n}\n",

calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        if (k <= 3 * n) {\n            int n3 = (k - 2 * n);\n He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k == 3 * n) {\n        return 0;\n    }\n    if (k < 3 * n) {\n        int n3 = k - The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    } else if (k > 2 * n && k <= 3 * n) {\n        return k - 2 * n;\n    } else if (k > 3 * n && k <= 4 * n) {\n        int n4 = (k - 2 * n) / 2;\n        int remainder = k - (2 * n4 + 3 * (n - n4));\n        return remainder > 0 ? n4 + (remainder + 2) / 3 : n4;\n    } else {\n        int n5 = (k - 3 * n) / 5;\n        if (n5 > n) {\n            n5 = n;\n        }\n        int remainder = k - (5 * n5 + 4 * (n - n5));\n        return remainder > 0 ? n5 + (remainder + 3) / 4 : n5;\n    }\n}\n",

                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k < 2 * n) {\n        return (k + 1) / 2;\n    }\n    if (k > 5 * n) {\n        return -1; He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    n5 = (k - 2 * n) / 5;\n    if (2 * n5 + 3 * (n - n5) >= k) {\n        return n - n5;\n    }\n\n    for (n5 = 0;                     "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        if (k <= 3 * n) {\n            int n3 = k - 2 * n;\n            return n3;\n        }\n        if (k <= 4 * n) {\n            int n3 = n;\n            int n4 = (k - 3 * n3) / (4 - 3);\n            if (n4 * 4 + (n - n4) * 3 >= k) {\n                return n4;\n            }\n            return n3;\n        }\n        int n4 = n;\n        int n5 = (k - 4 * n4) / (5 - 4);\n        if (n5 * 5 + (n - n5) * 4 >= k) {\n            return n5;\n        }\n        return n4;\n    }\n    return 0;\n}\n",

The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams.
