It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k < 2 * n) {\n        return k / 2;\n    }\n    if (k <= 3 * n) {\n        int n2 = (3 * n - k);\n        if (n2 >= 0 && n2 <= n) {\n            return n2;\n        }\n        int n3 = (k - 2 * n);\n        return n3;\n    }\n    if (k <= 4 * n) {\n        int n2 = (4 * n - k) / 2;\n        if (2 * n2 + 3 * (n - n2) == k && n2 <= n) {\n            return n2;\n        }\n        return (k - 3 * n) / 2;\n    }\n    int n2 = (5 * n - k) / 3;\n    if (2 * n2 + 3 * (n - n2) == k && n2 <= n) {\n        return n2;\n    }\n    int n3 = (k - 4 * n) / 2;\n    return n3;\n}\n",

He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        if (k <= 3 * n) {\n            return k - 2 * n;\n        }\n        if (k <= 4 * n) {\n            int n3 = (3 * n - k + 3 - 1) / 3;\n            int remaining = k - (3 * (n - n3) + 2 * n3);\n            if (remaining <= n3) {\n                return remaining;\n            } else {\n                return n3 + 1 + (remaining - He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int findConfiguration(int n, int k, int current) {\n        if (2 * current == k) return current;\n        if (2 * current < k && k <= 3 * (current + 1)) return k - 2 * current;\n        if (k > 3 * (current + 1)) return findConfiguration(n - 1, k - 5, current + 1);\n        return current;\n    }\n    return findConfiguration(n, k, 0);\n}\n",

                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    } else if (k < 2 * n) {\n        return 0;\n    } else {\n        if (k <= 3 * n) {\n            return k - \\result);\n*/\n```\nFUNCTION SIGNATURE:\n```c\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k);\n```\n--- END CONTEXT ---\n\n--- PREVIOUS ATTEMPT (did not verify) ---\n```c\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        if (k <= 3 * n) {\n            return k - 2 * n;\n        }\n        if (k <= 4 * n) {\n            int n3 = n - (k - 2 * n) / 2;\n            int additional = (k - (2 * (n - n3) + 3 * n3)) / 4;\n            return (n3 + 1 == n || 3 * n3 + 4 * additional == k) ? n3 He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (n == 1) {\n        return k == 2 ? 1 : 0;\n    }\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        if (k <= 3 * n) {\n            int n3 = (k - 2 * n + 2) / 3;\n            return n3;\n        }\n        int n4 = (k - 2 * n + 4) / 4;\n        int remainder = (k - 2 * n - (4 * n4)) % 4;\n        int extra = remainder == 0 ? 0 : 1;\n        return n4 + extra;\n    }\n    return 0;\n}\n",

calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        if (k <= 3 * n) {\n            return k - 2 * n;\n        }\n                     "tokens_used": 1378,
                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n && k <= 3 * n) {\n        int n3 = n - (k - 2 * n) / 2;\n        if (2 * (n - n3) + 3 * n3 == k) {\n            return n - n3;\n        }\n        return n - n3 + 1;\n    }\n    if (k > 3 * n && k <= 4 * n) {\n        int n3 = n - (k - 3 * n) / 3;\n        int additional = (k - (3 * (n - n3))) / 4;\n        if (3 * n3 + 4 * additional == k) {\n            return n - n3 + additional;\n        }\n        return n - n3 + additional + 1;\n    }\n    if (k > 4 * n && k <= 5 * n) {\n        int n4 = (k - 4 * n) / 4;\n        if (4 * n4 + 5 * (n - n4) == k) {\n            return n4;\n        }\n        return n4 + 1;\n    }\n    return 0; /* Safe default, should never occur due to preconditions */\n}\n",

                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        int n2, n3, n4, n5, result;\n        n5 = (k - 2 * n) / 5;\n        if (n5 > n) n5 = n;\n        k -= 5 * n5;\n        n -= n5;\n\n        n4 = (k - 2 * n) / 4;\n        if (n4 > n) n4 = n;\n        k -= 4 * n4;\n        n -= n4;\n\n        n3 = (k - 2 * n) / 3;\n        if (n3 > n) n3 = n;\n        k -= 3 * n3;\n        n -= n3;\n        \n        if (k <= 2 * n) {\n            n2 = (k + 2 - 1) / 2;\n        } else {\n            n2 = n;\n        }\n        \n        result = n2 + n3 + n4 + n5;\n        return result;\n    }\n    return 0;\n}\n",

requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n```\nFUNCTION SIGNATURE:\n```c\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k);\n```\n--- END CONTEXT ---\n\n--- PREVIOUS ATTEMPT (did not verify) ---\n```c\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        if (k <= 3 * n) {\n            return k - 2 * n;\n        }\n        if (k <= 4 * n) {\n            int n3 = (3 * n - k + 3 - 1) / 3;\n            int remaining = k - (3 * (n - n3) + 2 * n3);\n            if (remaining <= n3) {\n                return remaining;\n            } else {\n                return n3 + 1 + (remaining - n3 - 1) / 2 + 1;\n            }\n        }\n        int n4 = n;\n        int remaining = k - 3 * n4;\n        return n4 - remaining / 4;\n    }\n    return 0;\n}\n```\n--- VERIFICATION FEEDBACK ---\nThe verification timed out. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    int n2 = k / 2;\n    int remainder = k -                     "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k <= 3 * n) {\n        if (k > 2 * n) {\n            return k - 2 * n;\n        }\n        return 0;\n    }\n    if (k <= 4 * n) {\n        int n3 = (3 * n - k) / 3;\n        int n4 = n - n3;\n        int remaining = k - (3 * n4 + 2 * n3);\n        int n2 = n3 + (remaining + 1) / 2;\n        return n2 < n4 ? n2 : n4;\n    }\n    int n5 = n;\n    int remaining = k - 4 * n5;\n    int n6 = (remaining + 4 - 1) / 4;\n    return n - n6;\n}\n",

                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        if (k <= 3 * n) {\n            return k - 2 * n;\n        }\n        if (k <= 4 * n) {\n            int n3 = (3 * n - k + 3 - 1) / 3;\n            int remaining = k - (3 * (n - n3));\n            return n3 + ((remaining + 1) / 2);\n        }\n        int n4 = n;\n        int remaining = k - 3 * n4;\n        return n4 - (remaining + 4 - 1) / 4;\n    }\n    return 0;\n}\n",

He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        if (k <= 3 * n) {\n            return k - 2 * n;\n        }\n                     "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    if (k <= 2 * n) {\n        n2 = k / 2;\n        n3 = 0;\n        n4 = 0;\n        n5 = 0;\n    } else if (k <= 3 * n) {\n        n3 = (k - 2 * n);\n        n2 = n - n3;\n        n4 = 0;\n        n5 = 0;\n    } else if (k <= 4 * n) {\n        n4 = (k - 3 * n) / 4;\n        k -= 4 * n4;\n        n3 = (k - 2 * n) / 3;\n        n2 = n - n3 - n3 - n4 - n5;\n    }\n    return n2;\n}\n",

He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2_max = k / 2;\n    int n2_min = k >= 3 * n ? That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int remaining;\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        if (k <= 3 * n) {\n            return k - 2 * n;\n        }\n        if (k <= 4 * n) {\n            int n3 = (3 * n - k + 3 - 1) / 3;\n            remaining = k - (3 * (n - n3) + 2 * n3);\n            if (remaining <= n3) {\n                return remaining;\n            } else {\n                return n3 + 1 + (remaining - n3 - 1) / 2 + 1;\n            }\n        }\n        int n4 = n;\n        remaining = k - 3 * n4;\n        if (remaining % 4 == 0) {\n            return n4 - remaining / 4;\n        } else {\n            return n4 - remaining / 4 - 1;\n        }\n    }\n    return 0;\n}\n",

                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int result = n;\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    for (n5 = 0; He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5, result;\n    \n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        n2 = n;\n        n3 = 0;\n        n4 = 0;\n        n5 = 0;\n    } else {\n        n5 = (k - 2 * n) / 5;\n        if (n5 > n) n5 = n;\n        k -= 5 * n5;\n        n -= n5;\n\n        n4 = (k - 2 * n) / 4;\n        if (n4 > n) n4 = n;\n        k -= 4 * n4;\n        n -= n4;\n\n        n3 = (k - 2 * n) / 3;\n        if (n3 > n) n3 = n;\n        k -= 3 * n3;\n        n -= n3;\n\n        n2 = (k + 2 - 1) / 2;\n    }\n    \n    result = n2;\n    return result;\n}\n",

He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 2 * n) {\n        int n2, n3, n4, n5, result;\n        n5 = (k - 2 * n) / 5;\n That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    \n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    \n    n5 = k / 5;\n    if (n5 > n) n5 = n;\n    k -= 5 * n5;\n    n -= n5;\n    \n    n4 = k / 4;\n    if (n4 > n) n4 = n;\n    k -= 4 * n4;\n    n -= n4;\n    \n    n3 = k / 3;\n    if (n3 > n) n3 = n;\n    k -= 3 * n3;\n    n -= n3;\n    \n    n2 = k / 2;\n    if (n2 > n) n2 = n;\n    \n    return n2;\n}\n",

The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k > 5 * n) {\n        return n + 1; // Invalid to form such a configuration with given constraints\n    }\n\n    int result = n;\n    if (k > 0) {\n        int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n        n5 = (k - 2 * n) / 5;\n        if (n5 > n) n5 = n;\n\n        int remainder = k - n5 * 5;\n        int total = n5;\n        \n        n4 = remainder / 4;\n        if (n4 > n - total) n4 = n - total;\n\n        remainder -= n4 * 4;\n        total += n4;\n\n        n3 = remainder / 3;\n        if (n3 > n - total) n3 = n - total;\n\n        remainder -= n3 * 3;\n        total += n3;\n\n        n2 = remainder / 2;\n        if (n2 > n - total) n2 = n - total;\n        \n        total += n2;\n        if (remainder - n2 * 2 > 0) total++;\n\n        result = total;\n    }\n    return result;\n}\n",

He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    }\n    if (k == 3 * n) {\n        return 0;\n    }\n    if (k == 4 * n) {\n        return 0;\n    }\n    if (k == 5 * n) {\n        return 0;\n    }\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5, result;\n    n5 = (k - 1) / 2;\n    } else {\n        n2 = n;\n    }\n\n    result = n2 + n3 + n4 + n5;\n    return result;\n}\n",

                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 0) return 0;\n    int min_n2 = -1;\n    if (k >= 5) {\n        int max_n5 = k / 5 < n ?                     "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n; \n    }\n    int n5 = (k - 2 * n) / 5;\n    if (n5 > n) n5 = n;\n    k -= 5 * n5;\n    n -= n5;\n\n    int n4 = (k - 2 * n) / 4;\n    if (n4 > n) n4 = n;\n    k -= 4 * n4;\n    n -= n4;\n\n    int n3 = (k - 2 * n) / 3;\n    if (n3 > n) n3 = n;\n    k -= 3 * n3;\n    n -= n3;\n\n    int n2 = (k + 1) / 2;\n    return n2;\n}\n",

He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    } else {\n        int best_n2 = n; Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5, result;\n    \n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        n2 = n;\n        n3 = 0;\n        n4 = 0;\n        n5 = 0;\n    } else {\n        n5 = (k - 2 * n) / 5;\n        if (n5 > n) n5 = n;\n        k -= 5 * n5;\n        n -= n5;\n\n        n4 = (k - 2 * n) / 4;\n        if (n4 > n) n4 = n;\n        k -= 4 * n4;\n        n -= n4;\n\n        n3 = (k - 2 * n) / 3;\n        if (n3 > n) n3 = n;\n        k -= 3 * n3;\n        n -= n3;\n\n        n2 = (k + 1) / 2; \n\n        if (2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 != k || n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 != n) {\n            n2 = n3 = n4 = n5 = 0;\n            if (k >= 5 * n) {\n                n5 = n;\n            } else {\n                n5 = k / 5;\n            }\n            k -= 5 * n5;\n\n            if (k >= 4 * n) {\n                n4 = n;\n            } else {\n                n4 = k / 4;\n            }\n            k -= 4 * n4;\n\n            if (k >= 3 * n) {\n                n3 = n;\n            } else {\n                n3 = k / 3;\n            }\n            k -= 3 * n3;\n\n            n2 = (k + 1) / 2;\n        }\n    }\n    \n    result = n2;\n    return result;\n}\n",

                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n\n    if (k == 2 * n) {\n        return n;\n    } \n\n    for (n5 = 0; n5 <= n; ++n5) {\n        int remaining_k = k - 5 * n5;\n        int remaining_n = n - n5;\n        \n        for (n4 = 0; n4 <= remaining_n; ++n4) {\n            remaining_k -= 4 * n4;\n            remaining_n -= n4;\n\n            for (n3 = 0; n3 <= remaining_n; ++n3) {\n                remaining_k -= 3 * n3;\n                remaining_n -= n3;\n\n                if (remaining_k < 0) break;\n\n                n2 = remaining_k / 2;\n                if (n2 <= remaining_n && 2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k) {\n                    return n2;\n                }\n\n                remaining_k += 3 * n3;\n                remaining_n += n3;\n            }\n\n            remaining_k += 4 * n4;\n            remaining_n += n4;\n        }\n    }\n    \n    return 0;\n}\n",

He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (n == 0) return 0;\n\n    int n5 = k / 5;\n    if (n5 > n) n5 = n;\n    int remainder = k -                     "gpt_output": "```c\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    // Helper function to calculate minimum exams recursively\n    int helper(int n, int k, int current_n2) {\n        if (n == 0) {\n            return (k == 0) ? current_n2 : -1; // invalid case\n        }\n        \n        int result;\n        \n        // Try with maximum n5 (5 credits)\n        int n5_max = k / 5;\n        if (n5_max > n) n5_max = n;\n\n        for (int n5 = n5_max; n5 >= 0; n5--) {\n            int remaining_k = k - (5 * n5);\n            int remaining_n = n - n5;\n            \n            int n4_max = remaining_k / 4;\n            if (n4_max > remaining_n) n4_max = remaining_n;\n\n            for (int n4 = n4_max; n4 >= 0; n4--) {\n                remaining_k -= (4 * n4);\n                remaining_n -= n4;\n                \n                if (remaining_k < 0) continue;\n                \n                int n3_max = remaining_k / 3;\n                if (n3_max > remaining_n) n3_max = remaining_n;\n\n                for (int n3 = n3_max; n3 >= 0; n3--) {\n                    remaining_k -= (3 * n3);\n                    remaining_n -= n3;\n                    \n                    if (remaining_k < 0) continue;\n\n                    int n2 = remaining_k / 2;\n                    if (n2 <= remaining_n && (2 * n2 == remaining_k)) {\n                        return helper(remaining_n - n2, 0, current_n2 + n2);\n                    }\n                    \n                    remaining_k += (3 * n3);\n                    remaining_n += n3;\n                }\n\n                remaining_k += (4 * n4);\n                remaining_n += n4;\n            }\n        }\n\n        return -1; // No valid configuration found\n    }\n    \n    return helper(n, k, 0);\n}\n```",
                    "tokens_used": 1667,
                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    // Helper function to calculate minimum exams recursively\n    int helper(int n, int k, int current_n2) {\n        if (n == 0) {\n            return (k == 0) ? current_n2 : -1; // invalid case\n        }\n        \n        int result;\n        \n        // Try with maximum n5 (5 credits)\n        int n5_max = k / 5;\n        if (n5_max > n) n5_max = n;\n\n        for (int n5 = n5_max; n5 >= 0; n5--) {\n            int remaining_k = k - (5 * n5);\n            int remaining_n = n - n5;\n            \n            int n4_max = remaining_k / 4;\n            if (n4_max > remaining_n) n4_max = remaining_n;\n\n            for (int n4 = n4_max; n4 >= 0; n4--) {\n                remaining_k -= (4 * n4);\n                remaining_n -= n4;\n                \n                if (remaining_k < 0) continue;\n                \n                int n3_max = remaining_k / 3;\n                if (n3_max > remaining_n) n3_max = remaining_n;\n\n                for (int n3 = n3_max; n3 >= 0; n3--) {\n                    remaining_k -= (3 * n3);\n                    remaining_n -= n3;\n                    \n                    if (remaining_k < 0) continue;\n\n                    int n2 = remaining_k / 2;\n                    if (n2 <= remaining_n && (2 * n2 == remaining_k)) {\n                        return helper(remaining_n - n2, 0, current_n2 + n2);\n                    }\n                    \n                    remaining_k += (3 * n3);\n                    remaining_n += n3;\n                }\n\n                remaining_k += (4 * n4);\n                remaining_n += n4;\n            }\n        }\n\n        return -1; // No valid configuration found\n    }\n    \n    return helper(n, k, 0);\n}\n",
