The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2 = 0, n3 = 0, n4 = 0, n5 = 0;\n    \n    if (k >= 5 * n) {\n        n5 = n;\n        k -= 5 * n5;\n    } else {\n        n5 = k / 5;\n        k -= 5 * n5;\n    }\n    \n    if (k >= 4 * n) {\n        n4 = n - n5;\n        k -= 4 * n4;\n    } else {\n        n4 = k / 4;\n        k -= 4 * n4;\n    }\n    \n    if (k >= 3 * n) {\n        n3 = n - n5 - n4;\n        k -= 3 * n3;\n    } else {\n        n3 = k / 3;\n        k -= 3 * n3;\n    }\n    \n    n2 = k / 2;\n    return n2;\n}\n",

                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n\n    n5 = (k >= 5 * n) ? n : k / 5;\n    k -= 5 * n5;\n    n -= n5;\n\n    n4 = (k >= 4 * n) ? n : k / 4;\n    k -= 4 * n4;\n    n -= n4;\n\n    n3 = (k >= 3 * n) ? n : k / 3;\n    k -= 3 * n3;\n    n -= n3;\n\n    n2 = k / 2;\n\n    if (2 * n2 == k) {\n        return n2;\n    }\n    \n    return 0;\n}\n",

That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n5 = 0, n4 = 0, n3 = 0, n2 = 0;\n\n    n5 = k / 5;\n    if (n5 > n) n5 = n;\n    n -= n5;\n    k -= 5 * n5;\n\n    n4 = k / 4;\n    if (n4 > n) n4 = n;\n    n -= n4;\n    k -= 4 * n4;\n\n    n3 = k / 3;\n    if (n3 > n) n3 = n;\n    n -= n3;\n    k -= 3 * n3;\n\n    n2 = k / 2;\n    if (n2 > n) n2 = n;\n    n -= n2;\n    k -= 2 * n2;\n\n    if (k == 0) {\n        return n2;\n    }\n\n    return 0;\n}\n",

                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    /* Helper function to find the configuration */\n    int find_config(int n, int k, int n2) {\n        int n3, n4, n5;\n        if (n2 > n) return -1;\n\n        n5 = (k - 2 * n2) / 5;\n        if (n5 < 0 || n5 > n - n2) return -1;\n        \n        k -= 5 * n5;\n        \n        n4 = (k - 2 * n2) / 4;\n        if (n4 < 0 || n4 > n - n2 - n5) return -1;\n        \n        k -= 4 * n4;\n        \n        n3 = (k - 2 * n2) / 3;\n        if (n3 < 0 || n3 > n - n2 - n5 - n4) return -1;\n        \n        k -= 3 * n3;\n        \n        if (k == 2 * n2) return n2;\n        \n        return -1;\n    }\n    \n    /* Main recursive call to minimize resits */\n    int rec_helper(int n, int k, int current_min) {\n        if (n < 0) return current_min;\n        int result = find_config(n, k, n);\n        if (result != -1 && (current_min == -1 || result < current_min)) {\n            current_min = result;\n        }\n        return rec_helper(n - 1, k, current_min);\n    }\n    \n    return rec_helper(n, k, -1);\n}\n",

He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    \n    if (k == 0) return 0;\n\n    n5 = (k >= 5) ?                     "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5, remaining;\n\n    n5 = (k > 5 * n) ? n : k / 5;\n    remaining = k - 5 * n5;\n\n    n4 = (remaining > 4 * (n - n5)) ? n - n5 : remaining / 4;\n    remaining -= 4 * n4;\n\n    n3 = (remaining > 3 * (n - n5 - n4)) ? n - n5 - n4 : remaining / 3;\n    remaining -= 3 * n3;\n\n    n2 = (remaining > 2 * (n - n5 - n4 - n3)) ? n - n5 - n4 - n3 : remaining / 2;\n\n    return n2;\n}\n",

Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5;\n\n    n5 = k / 5;\n    if (n5 > n) n5 = n;\n    k -= 5 * n5;\n\n    n4 = k / 4;\n    if (n4 > n - n5) n4 = n - n5;\n    k -= 4 * n4;\n\n    n3 = k / 3;\n    if (n3 > n - n5 - n4) n3 = n - n5 - n4;\n    k -= 3 * n3;\n\n    n2 = k / 2;\n    if (n2 > n - n5 - n4 - n3) n2 = n - n5 - n4 - n3;\n\n    return n2;\n}\n",

He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int remaining_k = k;\n    int result_n2 = n + 1;                     "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2, n3, n4, n5, total_exams;\n    n5 = n4 = n3 = n2 = 0;\n\n    if (2 * n > k) {\n        n2 = (k + 1) / 2;\n    } else {\n        if (3 * n > k) {\n            n2 = 0;\n            n3 = (k - 2 * n + 2) / 3;\n        } else if (4 * n > k) {\n            n2 = n3 = 0;\n            n4 = (k - 3 * n + 3) / 4;\n        } else {\n            n2 = n3 = n4 = 0;\n            n5 = (k - 4 * n + 4) / 5;\n        }\n    }\n    total_exams = n - n5 - n4 - n3;\n    return total_exams >= 0 ? The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    int n2 = 0, n3 = 0, n4 = 0, n5 = 0;\n    \n    int remaining_k1 = k;\n    int remaining_n1 = n;\n    if (remaining_k1 > 0 && remaining_n1 > 0) {\n        n5 = remaining_k1 / 5 < remaining_n1 ? remaining_k1 / 5 : remaining_n1;\n        remaining_k1 -= 5 * n5;\n        remaining_n1 -= n5;\n    }\n    \n    int remaining_k2 = remaining_k1;\n    int remaining_n2 = remaining_n1;\n    if (remaining_k2 > 0 && remaining_n2 > 0) {\n        n4 = remaining_k2 / 4 < remaining_n2 ? remaining_k2 / 4 : remaining_n2;\n        remaining_k2 -= 4 * n4;\n        remaining_n2 -= n4;\n    }\n\n    int remaining_k3 = remaining_k2;\n    int remaining_n3 = remaining_n2;\n    if (remaining_k3 > 0 && remaining_n3 > 0) {\n        n3 = remaining_k3 / 3 < remaining_n3 ? remaining_k3 / 3 : remaining_n3;\n        remaining_k3 -= 3 * n3;\n        remaining_n3 -= n3;\n    }\n\n    int remaining_k4 = remaining_k3;\n    int remaining_n4 = remaining_n3;\n    if (remaining_k4 > 0 && remaining_n4 > 0) {\n        n2 = remaining_k4 / 2 < remaining_n4 ? remaining_k4 / 2 : remaining_n4;\n        remaining_k4 -= 2 * n2;\n        remaining_n4 -= n2;\n    }\n    \n    return n2;\n}\n",

                    "code": "/*One day the Codeforces round author sat exams. He had n exams and he needed to get an integer from 2 to 5 for each exam. He will have to re-sit each failed exam, i.e. the exam that gets mark 2 . The author would need to spend too much time and effort to make the sum of his marks strictly more than k . That could have spoilt the Codeforces round. On the other hand, if the sum of his marks is strictly less than k , the author's mum won't be pleased at all. The Codeforces authors are very smart and they always get the mark they choose themselves. Also, the Codeforces authors just hate re-sitting exams. Help the author and find the minimum number of exams he will have to re-sit if he passes the exams in the way that makes the sum of marks for all n exams equal exactly k .\n\n    Input\n    The input contains space-separated integers n and k (1 \u2264 n \u2264 50, 1 \u2264 k \u2264 250) \u2014 the number of exams and the required sum of marks. It is guaranteed that there exists a way to pass n exams in the way that makes the sum of marks equal exactly k .\n\n    Output\n    Output the single number \u2014 the minimum number of exams that the author will get a 2 for, considering that the sum of marks for all exams must equal k.\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate IsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    result == n2;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(integer n, integer k, integer result) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n &&\n    n2 < result;\n*/\n\n/*@\npredicate ExistsPossibleConfiguration(integer n, integer k) =\n    \\exists integer n2, n3, n4, n5;\n    0 <= n2 <= n &&\n    0 <= n3 <= n &&\n    0 <= n4 <= n &&\n    0 <= n5 <= n &&\n    2 * n2 + 3 * n3 + 4 * n4 + 5 * n5 == k &&\n    n2 + n3 + n4 + n5 == n;\n*/\n\n/*@\nrequires  1 <= n <= 50;\n    requires  1 <= k <= 250;\n    requires ExistsPossibleConfiguration(n, k);\n    assigns \\nothing;\n    ensures IsPossibleConfiguration(n, k, \\result);\n    ensures !ExistsSmallerAmountOfResits(n, k, \\result);\n*/\n\nint calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(int n, int k) {\n    if (k <= 2 * n) return k / 2;\n\n    if (k <= 3 * n) {\n        int n3 = (k - 2 * n) / (3 - 2);\n        k -= 3 * n3;\n        n -= n3;\n        return n3 + calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n, k);\n    }\n\n    if (k <= 4 * n) {\n        int n4 = (k - 3 * n) / (4 - 3);\n        k -= 4 * n4;\n        n -= n4;\n        return n4 + calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n, k);\n    }\n\n    int n5 = n;\n    k -= 5 * n5;\n    return n5 + calculateMinimumExamsToResitForGivenSum(n, k);\n}\n",
